question: Prayer is obligatory in all circumstances, especially in times of distress. - Even if war were chosen, prayer should precede it.  Therefore, making prayer sound merely conditional conflicts with its mandatory nature

Now we will explain why Yosef needed both proofs together, since each proof was a complete verification as mentioned above. If so, one should have been sufficient. One can explain that although it was verified to them through seeing the milah (circumcision) that he was a complete tzaddik (righteous person), as they saw upon him the Divine Presence (hashra'at Shemo Yitbarach) as mentioned above, and it was impossible to mistake him for an Arab who was circumcised or from the children of Keturah.

However, they still had room for doubt, as it was possible that there was another tzaddik in the land who guarded the bris (covenant) and had the holy name (shema kadisha) rest upon him, and he wasn't Yosef. Perhaps he was only changing his speech to ease their minds and for the sake of Heaven (l'shem shamayim) by saying he was Yosef, because he saw their spiritual distress. Also, since the tribes were prepared for war to kill him and the entire city as stated in the Midrash, they were concerned that perhaps he changed his speech in the way our Sages said it is permitted to change [the truth] for the sake of peace (mipnei darchei shalom), and perhaps he would later reveal to them that he wasn't their brother Yosef.

However, their doubts were resolved through seeing his language capability, for regarding the aspect of language that was at the level of "seeing what is heard," which is impossible except through the Divine Presence (hashra'at HaShechinah) speaking through his throat. From this they knew that his mouth and heart were aligned and he wasn't changing his speech, for the Divine Presence cannot rest upon false speech, Heaven forbid. If the words weren't truthful, even in a permitted way such as changing for the sake of peace or because of danger, it would have been impossible for the Shechinah to speak through his throat. Therefore, from this they knew with clear proof that truth was in his mouth and that he was indeed their brother Yosef.

This explains the words of the aforementioned Midrash where Yehudah said, "If I come for war, if I come for appeasement, if I come for prayer." This is based on what the holy Yismach Moshe wrote (in Parshat Vayeshev) in the name of the holy Kedushat Levi, that in the days of the Chashmonaim, the miracle was not complete because it came through war. The way of the Torah is that those below should not take any physical action, but rather [rely] only on prayer and supplication before the Holy One, Blessed be He.

However, there are times when Heaven agreed to war, such as in the days of the Chashmonaim, the Kohanim Gedolim who fought according to Ruach HaKodesh (Divine inspiration), and King David who fought his wars through the counsel of the Urim v'Tumim and Ruach HaKodesh. There were other kings who received Heaven's consent for war. There were also times when Heaven did not agree to fight against the nations, and they needed to appease them with gifts and bribe them with money, combined with the power of prayer, and in this way they were saved from them. In the future, the nations of the world will return all these gifts, as mentioned above.

In our times, these being Ikveta d'Meshicha (the footsteps of Mashiach), we have no permission to wage war against them, and we have no counsel or remedy except to pray to Hashem, and this is our only hope. Therefore, Yehudah mentioned all these three aspects, as he was king over the tribes, and Melech HaMashiach (King Messiah) will come from Yehudah. Thus, he enumerated all these times and aspects that Israel will experience until the coming of Mashiach.

This is what is meant by "if for war" - meaning if Heaven agrees to war and it is the Supreme Will, then I come to fight, alluding to David who comes from Yehudah, and also alluding to other kings who fought by Hashem's command, as Yehudah is the head of kingship. He also alluded to them by saying "I come." Similarly, "if for appeasement I come," and "if for prayer" - when it is the Supreme Will that salvation should come through prayer alone, then I come with the power of prayer.

This refers to Melech HaMashiach who comes from Yehudah, that Mashiach Tzidkeinu will come without physical action and without war. In truth, the power and merit of prayer must be combined with both war and appeasement. When it says "if for prayer," it means prayer alone, excluding war, and through the power of prayer alone Mashiach Tzidkeinu will come.

Unfortunately, in our days, hearts have become blocked, and we lack the ability to pour out speech and supplications with a complete heart. However, the power of prayer has already been prepared by the holy Avot and the Shevatim (tribes), as written in the holy Zohar (Parshat Toldot), that through the prayers of the tzaddikim, holiness increases and is added to all who need it, especially regarding the final exile and the future redemption, which they saw through their holy spirit and prayed for. The power and merit of their prayers are preserved for the time of grace when the appointed time comes, and surely it will help and assist that our prayers too will be accepted, Amen, so may it be His will.

Now when he made himself known to his brothers and said to them "I am Yosef, is my father still alive, etc." His brothers could have been puzzled and doubted the truthfulness of his words, for if his words were true, how could he have endured his father's pain for so many years without informing him, especially since he had the ability to do so as he was king and ruler, and who could question his actions? Therefore, he justified himself before them saying "Your eyes see that it is my mouth speaking to you," as explained by the Maor VaShemesh, that "you see that I speak only words that were sent to me from Heaven. This is why I did not inform my father."

The tribes (brothers) accepted his words as they saw their truth, for when he revealed himself to his brothers, his inner essence and spiritual level were revealed to them, which had been hidden and concealed from them throughout all this time until now.

Similarly, our father Yaakov, who accompanied Yosef to extend protection for his journey - he actually had the power to extend protection through his divine service and the power of his holiness even from his home. Therefore, Yosef said to him, "Return home." Yaakov replied, "My son, the mitzvah of accompaniment (levayah) is great, as alluded to in the passage of the eglah arufah (broken-necked heifer), where it states 'our hands did not spill this blood,' etc. Our Sages interpreted this to mean 'we did not send him away without accompaniment.'"

Our father Yaakov extended this power through his journey by means of the tikkunim and divine service of mitzvot that he accumulated along his way. This aspect is alluded to in the passage of eglah arufah through the mitzvah of accompaniment. Thus, we find that the matters of the covered wagons, Yosef's wagon, and the eglah arufah are all one concept and of the same spiritual aspect, and they all served as a metaphysical operation for the future.

Similarly were Judah's words, as written in the holy sefer Noam Elimelech (in Parshat Vayishlach) on the verse "Thus shall you say to my master, to Esau: 'I have sojourned with Laban, etc.'"

He [the Noam Elimelech] questioned why Jacob needed to mention and call Esau "my master" when speaking to the angels in his house. Also, the letter "lamed" in "l'Esau" (to Esau) seems unnecessary - he should have said "adoni Esau" (my master Esau). Furthermore, regarding Rashi's explanation that "I have sojourned with Laban" means "I kept the 613 mitzvot," would this really find favor in Esau's eyes?

Rather, the matter is that when a tzaddik speaks with people, he is precise in his words, ensuring that his words are heard in their simple meaning by the person he's speaking with, while the main content he intends with those words is prayer and supplication before HaKadosh Baruch Hu. The intention is to hide his words of prayer within the conversation he has with the person, and he doesn't explicitly state his needed prayer in order that the prosecutor (satan) won't understand his intention and won't prosecute him.

This is what Jacob said to the angels: "Thus shall you say" - in this manner and with this intention you should say all your words - "to my master," meaning your intention should be to the Master of All, the Blessed Creator, while also having a simple meaning for Esau that would be pleasing to him. This is why it says "Thus says your servant Jacob: 'I have sojourned with Laban,'" which can be understood in two ways: as words of advocacy before Hashem that he kept the 613 mitzvot, and this merit should protect him from Esau, and also in its simple meaning as words of appeasement and submission to Esau, that he was merely a stranger and didn't become important or powerful, as Rashi explains.

Similarly can be explained Judah's words to Joseph when he said "Please, my master, let your servant speak a word in my master's ears." When he mentioned "my master," the inner content of his words was prayer and supplication before the Creator, speaking words toward Above, but he concealed and clothed in his words also the simple meaning that would be words of appeasement and harsh words to Joseph. This explains well what our Sages said in the Midrash that this approach was for appeasement and for war with Joseph according to the simple meaning, and an approach of prayer to the Creator as mentioned above.

We can explain the verse "And to his father he sent 'like this' (k'zos): ten donkeys carrying from the best of Egypt, etc." The commentators were precise about the seemingly superfluous word "k'zos" (like this), as it would have been sufficient to say "and to his father he sent ten donkeys, etc."

This hints at our approach, based on what appears in the Midrash Rabbah (Parshas Acharei) on the verse "With this (b'zos) shall Aaron enter the Holy," which connects to the verse "L'David Hashem ori v'yishi (The Lord is my light and my salvation)." The Rabbis interpreted this verse regarding Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur - "ori" (my light) refers to Rosh Hashanah, and "yishi" (my salvation) to Yom Kippur. Throughout the year, the Satan accuses, but on Yom Kippur he cannot accuse. Israel said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: "Even if an army of Samael encamps against me, my heart will not fear, for You promised me 'With this shall Aaron enter the Holy.'"

Further in the Midrash, Rabbi Yudan interpreted the verse regarding the Kohen Gadol's entry into the Holy of Holies, saying he had many bundles of mitzvos in his merit: The merit of Torah ("And this is the Torah"), the merit of circumcision ("This is My covenant"), the merit of Shabbos ("Fortunate is the man who does this"), the merit of the tribes ("And this is what their father spoke to them"), the merit of terumah, the merit of sacrifices, etc. All these are hinted at in the verse "With this shall Aaron enter the Holy," and through these merits, he silenced the accuser over Israel.

Similarly, we can interpret the verse "And to his father he sent 'like this,'" indicating that he informed his father that he acted like the Kohen Gadol on Yom Kippur, and through all these merits hinted at in the word "zos," he silenced and subdued the accuser. Therefore, he should not fear coming to Egypt. This is what he hinted to his father with the word "zos," and separately from this, he sent ten donkeys carrying from the best of Egypt. Thus, the word "k'zos" is not referring to the ten donkeys but is a separate matter entirely.
